p:
Other studies suggest that both locations are important. In Shanghai, China,
103 there was a marked shift from 2007 to 2008 in the proportion of cases among children in preschools (from 59% to 37%) with a concurrent shift from local to migrant children, suggesting that the importance of routes of transmission can vary over time within the same locale. A case-control study from Zhejiang
94 showed that although attending preschool is a risk factor (OR: 2.1), other factors such as contact with neighbors (OR: 11), going to hospital (OR: 20) and going to parties (OR: 31) impart greater risk. Yet, a Korean case-control study
95 found no significant relationship between infection and school attendance or household size.
